Title.evidence: Long-term Outcomes of Immediate vs. Postponed Drainage in Infected Necrotizing Pancreatitis: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: A total of 104 patients with infected necrotizing pancreatitis were randomised

Participants.evidence: 104 patients with infected necrotizing pancreatitis were randomised to immediate catheter drainage (55 patients) or postponed catheter drainage (49 patients)

Intervention.evidence: randomised to immediate catheter drainage (55 patients) or postponed catheter drainage (49 patients)

Objective.evidence: The POINTER trial evaluated the long-term outcomes of immediate versus postponed drainage in patients with infected necrotizing pancreatitis.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was a composite of death and major complications, assessed over a median follow-up of 51 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 104 patients with infected necrotizing pancreatitis were randomised to immediate catheter drainage (55 patients) or postponed catheter drainage (49 patients) between August 2015 and October 2019.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of the 104 patients, 88 were re-evaluated after the initial 6-month follow-up.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome occurred in 7 of 47 patients (15%) in the immediate-drainage group and 7 of 41 patients (17%) in the postponed-drainage group (RR 0.87, 95% CI 0.33–2.28; P = 0.78).

Harms.evidence: No significant differences in adverse events were reported between groups.

Funding.evidence: This research did not receive any specific funding.
